
An intern encrypted a secret with RSA, but used a modulus built from two Blum primes. The flawed setup exposes the message: 1840706016692741705320166583648353648997258992544932221212290576236528401484965808623922014680171390432758104652387752427206896300765672104462998938064592


The flag format is flag{...}
n=7547998118307692651373280993468183251398385230827023107371579216573033924583458547124381805158361711330173580190565832688894170703787737104662384301744657, e=4594578042136104832823837006015667359728391023439567616264584794715631634316994919530500210540600677900629369639860578543522990886366500109035987663257137
The lower 104 bits of p are: 48003594804329628649493156552686712335


---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{zpifmblg}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 1840706016692741705320166583648353648997258992544932221212290576236528401484965808623922014680171390432758104652387752427206896300765672104462998938064592
vulnerability: blum integers
hint: Blum integers are products of primes congruent to 3 modulo 4. These integers have unique properties in cryptography.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=7547998118307692651373280993468183251398385230827023107371579216573033924583458547124381805158361711330173580190565832688894170703787737104662384301744657, e=4594578042136104832823837006015667359728391023439567616264584794715631634316994919530500210540600677900629369639860578543522990886366500109035987663257137
The lower 104 bits of p are: 48003594804329628649493156552686712335

extra_info: p=113427555188247014112420469716299159591783157027153515084463046045214908102159, q=66544660208719645433212494263421354421992728866402395021985416797365799405023, Ï†(n)=7547998118307692651373280993468183251398385230827023107371579216573033924583278574908984838498816078366193859676552056803000614793681288641819803594237476
subtype: blum_integers
